Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Story:
I walked into our apartment, briefcase in hand, and found Alex slumped on the couch, eyes red and jaw clenched. He barely looked up as I set my things down. “Bad day?” I asked, already knowing the answer. He nodded, voice cracking as he told me about the harsh feedback from his boss. My heart ached to comfort him, to sit beside him and listen, to reassure him that he was more than his job.

But as he spoke, my phone buzzed—a reminder about the new case file waiting in my chambers. The hearing was in two weeks, but I knew how important it was to review the details early, to ensure nothing slipped through the cracks. The expectation to be thorough, to uphold justice, pressed on me. I could almost feel the weight of the file in my bag, demanding my attention.

Alex needed me now, needed my empathy and presence. But the judge in me whispered about duty, about preparation and responsibility. I stood in the hallway, torn, feeling the pull of both worlds, unsure which part of me should take the lead tonight.
